reviews.text: The word “messy” is bandied around by its characters but The Life List is far too clean.
reviews.author: Benjamin Lee

reviews.text: There are moments in this film that can feel overly manipulative, but if you let yourself get swept up in the characters, you might find this a meaningful and rewarding journey.
reviews.author: Jennifer Green

reviews.text: Netflix’s The Life List is a romantic drama that is far too long but has such an adorable performance from its star, Sofia Carson.
reviews.author: M.N. Miller

reviews.text: While The Life List can't entirely avoid some shallowness, it's a cozy watch with a strong message made stronger by Sofia Carson's performance.
reviews.author: Rachel LaBonte

reviews.text: "The Life List" is painstakingly safe. It has no conflict, let alone an edge.
reviews.author: Robert Levin

reviews.text: For the most part, The Life List is cute... but it is also emotionally charged.
reviews.author: Rachel Leishman

reviews.text: The ever-endearing former Disney Channel staple Carson is capable of bearing the load of its light comedy and middleweight drama, even when the character written for her is about a quarter-shade shy of being a recognizable three-dimensional human being.
reviews.author: John Serba

reviews.text: The Life List reminds viewers about the importance of taking a step back and assessing the situation.
reviews.author: Nicholas Brooks

reviews.text: A few key arcs had the potential to be emotionally moving, but the constant use of vignettes as storytelling devices removes just about all of the impact a storyline contains.
reviews.author: Chris Joyce

reviews.text: An overlong and uninvolving romantic drama.
reviews.author: Casey Chong

reviews.text: It has appealing elements, most notably its winsome heroine, who unearths some gumption and gets back on the path to self-fulfillment.
reviews.author: Lynn Venhaus

reviews.text: “The Life List” won’t change your life but neither will it feel like a waste of time. It’s not great, but it’s good enough in a pinch. You could easily do worse.
reviews.author: Michael Clark

reviews.text: Much like a “Live, Laugh, Love” cross-stitch has its place in a certain type of home, The Life List has its place as a cathartic tearjerker for those who care more about life-affirming stories than quality filmmaking.
reviews.author: Caroline Siede

reviews.text: It’s frustratingly more concerned with telling us how she’s financially able to afford having a quarter-life identity crisis than it is with giving her journey toward enlightenment any genuine, satiating sense of internal transformation.
reviews.author: Courtney Howard

reviews.text: The Life List is exactly what it appears to be: a sentimental, by-the-numbers drama that never truly surprises or challenges its audience.
reviews.author: Roberto Tyler Ortiz

reviews.text: Though it's billed as a romance, The Life List is at its best when it allows itself to be a mother/daughter story.
reviews.author: Callie Hanna

reviews.text: Even though the romantic elements aren't as rewarding as the familial ties at the heart of The Life List, the project still has its merits.
reviews.author: Isabella Soares

reviews.text: [T]he shallow romance angle suffocates everything around it.
reviews.author: Mark Dujsik

reviews.text: With little flair, flat characters, and a script that pretty much writes itself, it’s another unmemorable Netflix film that joins the abyss of forgotten-about movies on the streaming platform.
reviews.author: Ema Sasic

reviews.text: Now that I have watched The Life List, I have come to the realization that the wealthy will be unrelatable even when it comes to experiencing something as universal as death.
reviews.author: Pramit Chatterjee

synopsis: When Alex Rose's mother sends her on a quest to complete her childhood bucket list, it takes her on a journey that will make you both laugh and cry as she uncovers family secrets, finds romance, and discovers herself along the way.
